title: Banks remove apps from Google Play store over Samsung security flaw
text:
Mobile banking customers have been put at risk by a security flaw relating to the fingerprint scanner on some Samsung mobile phones, a number of banks have said.

Some, including NatWest and Bank of Scotland, have temporarily removed their apps from the Google Play store – which is available on Samsung phones – until the issue has been rectified.

The nature of the flaw is unclear but it is understood to be due to be fixed via an update. Samsung has been approached for comment.

The BBC reported that the devices could be unlocked by anyone via a fingerprint scanner when used with certain screen protectors.

Bank of Scotland this afternoon warned customers to disable the fingerprint scanner on its app. It tweeted: "Samsung has a security issue with the fingerprint reader on its Galaxy Note 10/10+ and S10/S10+/S10 5G devices. There’s no problem with your mobile banking app, but for now you should turn off fingerprint log in. Samsung plans to update its software soon to fix the issue."
description: Mobile banking customers have been put at risk by a security flaw relating to the fingerprint scanner on some Samsung mobile phones, a number of banks have said.
